item.title: Josh O’Connor’s Masterly 2025 Performances: ‘Wake Up Dead Man: A Knives Out Mystery’ and More
item.description: The star’s nuance and emotional power, along with his natural charisma, quietly enriched a quartet of movies in 2025.
item.dc:creator: Manohla Dargis
item.category: Wake Up Dead Man: A Knives Out Mystery (Movie)

item.title: Can Timothée Chalamet Break This Oscar Curse?
item.description: The best actor Oscar almost never goes to young men, though the 30-year-old has his best chance yet with “Marty Supreme.”
item.dc:creator: Kyle Buchanan

item.title: Can Shawn Levy Resuscitate ‘Star Wars’?
item.description: Lucasfilm hopes that Shawn Levy, who made “Deadpool and Wolverine” and helped make “Stranger Things,” can bring that same touch. The key may be his inner child.
item.dc:creator: Calum Marsh
item.media:credit: Max Miechowski for The New York Times
item.media:description: “I’m the guy the studios call when they want someone they know will take their investment seriously and deliver responsibly,” Shawn Levy said.

item.title: The Movie That Inspired Michael Mann to Direct
item.description: “The Joyless Street” is among the most chopped-up films of the silent era. A restoration at MoMA’s To Save and Project series proves eye-opening.
item.dc:creator: Ben Kenigsberg

item.title: ‘Magellan’ Review: The Beauty and the Bloodshed of a Smaller World
item.description: Gael García Bernal plays the explorer Ferdinand Magellan in Lav Diaz’s portrait of a brutal adventurer and his travels across the globe.
item.dc:creator: Manohla Dargis

item.title: ‘Young Mothers’ Review: Teen Parents, Breaking Cycles
item.description: The Dardenne brothers’ latest film is a tender portrait of four teenage moms in a Belgian maternity shelter.
item.dc:creator: Alissa Wilkinson

item.title: The Cast and Creators of ‘KPop Demon Hunters’ on How the Movie Came to Be
item.description: As the filmmakers, songwriters and actors tell it, their “wackadoo” concept evolved over nine years and eight versions of “Golden” into a global phenomenon.
item.dc:creator: Melena Ryzik

item.title: To Be or Not to Be: That Is the Question Filmmakers Can’t Resist
item.description: The Shakespearean monologue that is featured twice in “Hamnet” has long informed the movies, often in surprising ways that can make us rethink the words.
item.dc:creator: Alissa Wilkinson
item.category: Star Trek VI: The Undiscovered Country (Movie)
To Be or Not to Be (Movie)

item.title: Bela Tarr, Titan of Slow-Moving Cinema, Dies at 70
item.description: The master Hungarian filmmaker’s movies included “Satantango” and “Werckmeister Harmonies.”
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall and Adam Nossiter
item.media:description: Bela Tarr in 2023. “I’m working for 30 years, and I’m doing the same movie,” he said. “About human dignity.”

item.title: ‘Bug’ Review: Carrie Coon Is Superb in an American Gothic Tale
item.description: Tracy Letts’s eerily topical, decades-old play about a woman’s descent into a world of conspiracy theories makes its nerve-rattling Broadway debut.
item.dc:creator: Jason Zinoman
item.media:description: Carrie Coon and Namir Smallwood in Tracy Letts’s stylistically slippery “Bug” at the Samuel J. Friedman Theater in Manhattan.

item.title: ‘People We Meet on Vacation’ Review: When Stuffy Met Silly
item.description: Love grows between a restless travel writer and a contented homebody in this occasionally cute, instantly forgettable romantic comedy.
item.dc:creator: Jeannette Catsoulis

item.title: Amos Poe, New York’s No Wave Film Pioneer, Dies at 76
item.description: He documented the punk and post-punk music scene in the East Village, leading an independent film movement that was proudly unprofessional.
item.dc:creator: Penelope Green

item.title: 2026 Directors Guild Nominations: ‘One Battle,’ ‘Sinners’
item.description: The films of Paul Thomas Anderson and Ryan Coogler have been competing all season. Also in the running are Guillermo del Toro, Josh Safdie and Chloé Zhao.
item.dc:creator: Kyle Buchanan

item.title: ‘Greenland 2: Migration’ Review: The New World
item.description: Gerard Butler returns for more earthshaking action in this crowd-pleasing postapocalyptic thriller.
item.dc:creator: Robert Daniels

item.title: ‘OBEX’ Review: An Analog Nightmare
item.description: In this indie oddity boasting visceral D.I.Y. effects, a gentle loner enters the world of a video game to save his beloved dog.
item.dc:creator: Beatrice Loayza

item.title: ‘My Neighbor Adolf’ Review: The Nazi Next Door
item.description: The actors Udo Kier and David Hayman square off in this domestic drama where a man is convinced that his neighbor is Adolf Hitler.
item.dc:creator: Glenn Kenny

item.title: ‘Holding Liat’ Review: Hostage Situation
item.description: This unpredictable documentary follows a man and his family as they wait for news of his daughter and her husband, who were kidnapped in the Hamas-led Oct. 7, 2023, attacks on Israel.
item.dc:creator: Nicolas Rapold
item.media:description: Yehuda Beinin, left, and Tal Beinin in the documentary “Holding Liat.”

item.title: ‘Dead Man’s Wire’ Review: When the Action Is Razor Thin
item.description: Dramatizing an odd news item from 1977, Gus Van Sant’s crime film isn’t crazy enough.
item.dc:creator: Ben Kenigsberg

item.title: ‘All That’s Left of You’ Review: Hearts, Minds, History
item.description: The Palestinian American director Cherien Dabis offers eloquent context with her generational drama about Palestinian men.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Kennedy

item.title: Interview: Tilda Swinton on Her Favorite Books and Favorite Collaborators
item.description: Starring in the 1992 film adaptation helped launch an eclectic career. “Ongoing” is the book that accompanies a retrospective on her work.

item.title: Arthur Cohn, Film Producer With an Oscar-Winning Touch, Dies at 98
item.description: Six of his movies received Academy Awards, including the Italian drama “The Garden of the Finzi-Continis” and the trade-union strike documentary “American Dream.”
item.dc:creator: Adam Nossiter
item.media:description: Arthur Cohn in his office in Basel, Switzerland, in 2000. “I search for projects that are out of the ordinary, enriching and apt to be remembered for a long time,” he said.

item.title: 2026 SAG Actor Award Nominations List: ‘One Battle’ and ‘Sinners’ Lead
item.description: Timothée Chalamet and Ariana Grande also scored nods. Cynthia Erivo and the stars of “Jay Kelly” were left out.
item.dc:creator: Kyle Buchanan

item.title: Nick Reiner’s Lawyer, Alan Jackson, Removes Himself From Murder Case
item.description: Mr. Reiner, who is charged with killing his parents, will now be represented by a public defender. His arraignment has been rescheduled for next month.
item.dc:creator: Tim Arango and Matt Stevens
item.media:description: Nick Reiner was charged with two counts of first-degree murder. If he is convicted, he could face a life sentence without parole or the death penalty.

item.title: Rosa von Praunheim, 83, Dies; Captured Gay Life in Germany on Film
item.description: His first feature-length movie, in 1971, was called his country’s “Stonewall moment,” for jump-starting a gay-rights movement. He became a leading voice of it.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen
item.category: It Is Not the Homosexual Who Is Perverse, but the Society in Which He Lives (Movie)
item.media:credit: Ulrich Heinemann-Rufer/ullstein bild, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Rosa von Praunheim in 1972. He was a leading figure within the New German Cinema movement.

item.title: Mickey Rourke Declines $100,000 in Donations After His Eviction
item.description: Rourke’s landlord said in court documents that the actor owed nearly $60,000 in rent. Rourke said he had opted not to pay rent after the home became uninhabitable.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor
item.media:credit: Nina Westervelt for The New York Times
item.media:description: The actor Mickey Rourke in New York in 2019.

item.title: Critics Choice Awards 2026: Unforgettable Looks From Ariana Grande, Megan Stalter and More
item.description: Saturated colors, sculptural silhouettes, doses of whiplash and more.
item.dc:creator: The Styles Desk
item.media:description: The actress Erin Doherty wore a strapless gown in an uplifting shade of spearmint.

item.title: The Best Movies and TV Shows Coming to Disney+, Amazon, HBO Max, Peacock and More in January
item.description: “The Pitt” Season 2, “Star Trek: Starfleet Academy,” “The Beauty,” “Wonder Man,” “Shrinking” Season 3 and more arrive.
item.dc:creator: Noel Murray

item.title: The Most Anticipated Book Adaptations of 2026: Movies and TV Shows
item.description: “People We Meet on Vacation,” “Wuthering Heights” and “Project Hail Mary” are some of this year’s most anticipated adaptations.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Harlan

item.title: Critics Choice Awards 2026: The Complete Winners List
item.description: “One Battle After Another” won best picture, while the top acting honors went to Timothée Chalamet (“Marty Supreme”) and Jessie Buckley (“Hamnet”).
item.dc:creator: Kyle Buchanan
item.media:description: From left, Benicio del Toro, Leonardo DiCaprio, the casting director Cassandra Kulukundis, the director Paul Thomas Anderson and Chase Infiniti, accepting best picture for “One Battle After Another.”

item.title: Kevin O’Leary on ‘Marty Supreme’ and Notes He Gave Josh Safdie
item.description: When it came to his film acting debut, the“Shark Tank” investor had some notes for the director Josh Safdie.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Bahr
item.media:description: For the movie, O’Leary wore two watches, one on each wrist: one set to New York time, the other set to Tokyo time.

item.title: Five Horror Movies to Stream Now
item.description: A new year brings thrillers galore, with evil emerging from a pandemic, a summer camp and a rideshare app.
item.dc:creator: Erik Piepenburg

item.title: On ‘Best Medicine,’ Josh Charles Has a Heart
item.description: After years of playing smarmy characters, the actor is stepping up as the lead in a comedy about a grumpy but charming doctor.
item.dc:creator: Alexis Soloski
item.media:credit: Peter Fisher for The New York Times
item.media:description: “It’s been feast or famine,” the actor Josh Charles said of his career in movies, TV and theater. He added: “I just want to do good work.”
